claim: US Airways Flight 1549 had 1978 people on board.

supporting.text: Official reports from the National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) state that US Airways Flight 1549 had 150 passengers and 5 crew members on board, totaling 155 people.

attacks.text: Official reports from the National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) state that US Airways Flight 1549 had 150 passengers and 5 crew members on board, totaling 155 people.
The claim of 1978 people is based on a misinterpretation of the flight number (1549) as the passenger count.
The aircraft type (Airbus A320) used for Flight 1549 has a maximum capacity of around 180 passengers, making 1978 impossible.
Flight numbers are often reused over time, so interpreting them as passenger counts is unreliable.
Aviation regulations strictly limit passenger numbers based on safety and aircraft specifications.
Historical data shows no commercial flight has ever carried close to 1978 passengers due to physical and regulatory constraints.

supporting.text: The Airbus A320-214, the aircraft model used for Flight 1549, has a maximum seating capacity of around 180 passengers, making it impossible to carry 1978 people.

attacks.text: The Airbus A320-214, the aircraft model used for Flight 1549, has a maximum seating capacity of around 180 passengers, making it impossible to carry 1978 people.
The claim might include crew members and ground staff, not just passengers, which could inflate the number.
The figure of 1978 could be a typographical error or miscommunication, as such discrepancies are common in initial reports.
Even including all crew and ground staff, the total would not exceed 200, far below 1978.
Official reports and airline documentation consistently list the maximum capacity as under 200, making a typo unlikely to account for such a large discrepancy.
Historical data shows that no commercial flight has ever reported such an extreme passenger count, supporting the implausibility of the claim.

supporting.text: Media coverage and survivor accounts consistently report a much smaller number of people on board, contradicting the claim of 1978 passengers and crew.

attacks.text: Media coverage and survivor accounts consistently report a much smaller number of people on board, contradicting the claim of 1978 passengers and crew.
Official flight manifests and airline records confirm that US Airways Flight 1549 had only 155 people on board, making the claim of 1978 impossible.
The capacity of an Airbus A320, the aircraft used for Flight 1549, is limited to around 150-180 passengers, which further disproves the claim of 1978 people.
Flight manifests can sometimes contain errors or be incomplete, so they may not be entirely reliable for verifying passenger counts.
Aircraft capacity limits are based on standard configurations, but emergency situations or special arrangements could theoretically allow for higher numbers.
Airline regulations and safety standards strictly enforce passenger limits, making it highly unlikely for any flight to exceed its certified capacity.

supporting.text: The claim may be a misinterpretation or typographical error, confusing the year of the incident (2009) with the number of people on board.

attacks.text: The claim may be a misinterpretation or typographical error, confusing the year of the incident (2009) with the number of people on board.
The claim is likely a deliberate exaggeration or fabrication, as no commercial aircraft can carry nearly 2000 passengers.
Official reports confirm US Airways Flight 1549 had only 155 people on board, making the original claim clearly false.
While the number is incorrect, it could be an honest mistake in transcription rather than deliberate exaggeration.
The discrepancy might stem from confusion with another aviation incident that had higher casualties.
Even as a transcription error, such a large numerical discrepancy suggests negligence in fact-checking.

supporting.text: Aviation safety records and databases do not list any commercial flight with close to 1978 passengers, as such a number would require an aircraft far larger than any currently in operation.

attacks.text: Aviation safety records and databases do not list any commercial flight with close to 1978 passengers, as such a number would require an aircraft far larger than any currently in operation.
Historical records show that some military or experimental flights have carried close to or more than 1978 passengers, which could be misclassified or omitted from commercial databases.
The claim might refer to a hypothetical or fictional scenario, not an actual flight, making the argument about real-world aircraft capacity irrelevant.
Errors in passenger manifest reporting or data entry could result in an inflated number like 1978 being recorded, even if it exceeds physical capacity.
Military or experimental flights are strictly documented separately and would not be confused with commercial flights like US Airways Flight 1549.
If the claim were fictional, it would likely specify this context to avoid confusion with real-world aviation incidents.
Passenger manifests are cross-checked rigorously for safety and legal reasons, making extreme errors like a 1978-passenger count highly improbable.
Classification errors between military and commercial flights have occurred in the past, especially in older or less regulated databases.
Even with rigorous checks, human or system errors can propagate in large datasets, especially under time pressure or during emergencies.
